div.l: And hadde a wiff that helde for a contynaunce
A shoppe ⁊and swyved for hir sustynaunce
Here endith the Cook his tale

And next folwith
the Clerke of Oxonford is prolog
Sir clerke of Oxenford oure ost sayde
Ye ride as inoy ⁊and stille as a mayde
Were newe spoused sittyng at the borde
This day herde I of youre tonge no worde
I trowe ye studie aboughte Som Sophyme
But Salomon seith eủery thing hath tyme
For godis sake as bethe of better chere
Hit is no tyme for to studie here
Telle vs som mery tale by youre feye
For what man that is entrid in to pleye
He nedis mote vn to the pley assente
But prechith nought as frerisfreros doon in lente
To make vs as for oure olde synnys wepe
Ne that thi tale make vs not to slepe
Telle vs som mery thing of auenturis
Youre t̉ermes youre colouris ⁊and your figuris
Kepe hem in store / til tyme that ye endite
Highe stile as whan men to kynges write
Speke so playne / at this tyme I yow preye
That we may vnderstonde / what ye seye
This worthy clerke benynglye answerde
Ost quod he I am vnder youre yerde
Ye haue of vs as now the goủernaunce
And therfore wol I do yow obeysaunce
As fer as reson axith hardelye
I wol yow telle a tale which that I
Lerned at Padowe of a worthi Clerke
As previd his wordis ⁊and his werke
He is now dede ⁊and nayled in his Cheste
I pray to god so yeve his soule god reste
Fraunces Petriak the lauriate poete
Hight this clerke whos Rethorikes swete
